This patient ingested a small amount of ibuprofen (800 mg = 40 mg/kg of body weight) with no other coingestants, and he has only mild symptoms. It would be safe to observe him until 4 to 6 hours after ingestion and, if he continued to do well, discharge him.

Key learning point: Activated charcoal is recommended for managing an ibuprofen overdose only if it is administered within one hour after the overdose.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring a serum level of ibuprofen is not useful in the acute management of ibuprofen ingestion, as it does not correlate well with improved outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

N- acetylcysteine is used to treat an acetaminophen overdose but has no appropriate role in an ibuprofen overdose.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastric emptying by gastric lavage or syrup of ipecac is not recommended, as it is not sufficiently effective.

E) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal can help reduce absorption of ingested ibuprofen, but it is recommended only if it can be administered within one hour after an overdose.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a fire in his apartment complex. He briefly lost consciousness while he was trapped in a smoke-filled room before firefighters were able to free him 20 minutes later. He reports headache, dizziness, and occasional cough. He has no difficulty breathing, speaking, or swallowing. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 155/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Breath sounds are coarse. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.30


PCO2

38 mm Hg


PO2

70 mm Hg


HCO3-

18 mEq/L


COHb
2% (N < 3)


In addition to oxygen supplementation with a non-rebreather mask, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous dimercaprol is a therapy for metal toxicity (e.g., arsenic, mercury, lead, or gold toxicity). This drug does not play a role in the treatment of cyanide toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is the first-line treatment for carbon monoxide toxicity, which is caused by smoke inhalation and can manifest with headache, confusion, nausea, vomiting, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness. This patient's normal carboxyhemoglobin levels make carbon monoxide toxicity unlikely. Patients with cyanide toxicity should receive treatment with 100% oxygen; hyperbaric oxygen therapy, however, is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylene blue is the treatment of choice for methemoglobinemia. This drug acts by reducing the ferric iron (Fe3+) of methemoglobin (unable to bind oxygen) back to the ferrous iron (Fe2+) of hemoglobin. Patients with methemoglobinemia typically present after exposure to an oxidizing agent (e.g., nitrates, dapsone) with clinical signs of cyanosis but normal PO2 on arterial blood gas analysis. Methylene blue was used in the treatment of cyanide poisoning, but it is no longer used for such treatment because it can release free cyanide and thereby worsen cyanide toxicity.

D) CORRECT:

All patients with suspected acute cyanide poisoning should receive antidotal treatment in addition to supportive measures (e.g., 100% oxygen therapy) and body surface decontamination. Cyanide poisoning is primarily a clinical diagnosis, and antidotal treatment should not be delayed for further diagnostic testing. Intravenous hydroxocobalamin is the first-line antidote because it acts rapidly, does not affect tissue oxygenation, and has minimal adverse effects. Hydroxocobalamin binds cyanide directly, forming cobalamin, which is then excreted in urine. This drug can be coadministered with sodium thiosulfate to enhance cyanide elimination.

Alternative treatment for patients with cyanide poisoning includes nitrites (e.g., amyl or sodium nitrite), which induce methemoglobinemia. Cyanide preferentially binds to methemoglobin, forming the compound cyanomethemoglobin and freeing cytochrome complex IV to resume oxidative phosphorylation. Because of the risk of worsening tissue hypoxia, this therapy should not be used in patients with inhalation injury unless concomitant carbon monoxide toxicity has been excluded.

E) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is an antioxidant used to restore depleted hepatic glutathione in patients with acetaminophen toxicity. It does not play a role in the treatment of cyanide toxicity.
questions.hint: Burning household items (e.g., plastics, furniture, rubber) can release cyanide, which causes toxicity seconds after inhalation. Cyanide binds to the mitochondrial cytochrome complex, which increases anaerobic metabolism and causes lactic acidosis. This patient's neurologic symptoms (e.g., headache, dizziness) and metabolic acidosis following smoke inhalation should raise concern for cyanide intoxication.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his neighbor found him collapsed on his front porch in a pool of vomitus. He is oriented only to self. Pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination shows muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Serum studies show:


Na+

137 mEq/L


Cl-

99 mEq/L


HCO3-

8 mEq/L


Serum osmolar gap is elevated. Urinalysis shows oxalate crystals. This patient is most likely experiencing toxicity from which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methanol is an alcohol that is metabolized to formate, a toxic substance that can cause end-organ damage. Although methanol poisoning would explain many of this man's symptoms (anion gap, altered mental status, elevated serum osmolar gap), the key distinguishing feature in this patient is the formation of urine oxalate crystals, which is not seen with methanol toxicity.

B) CORRECT:

Ethylene glycol is enzymatically oxidized by alcohol dehydrogenase, then aldehyde dehydrogenase, to form oxalate, glyoxylate, and glycolate. These metabolites collect in the renal system and are detectable in the urine as oxalate crystals, which can cause flank pain, hematuria, oliguria, and acute kidney injury. Hypocalcemia, the cause of this patient's tetany, is a result of calcium being consumed by oxalate to form calcium oxalate. Other signs of ethylene glycol poisoning include altered mental status and tachypnea (due to respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis). Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning consists of fomepizole to competitively inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase, as ethylene glycol itself is not nearly as toxic as its metabolites.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathion is an organophosphate that can cause cholinergic toxicity. Although this patient's altered mental status and vomiting may also be seen in organophosphate poisoning, oxalate crystals would not be seen. Additionally, he lacks the other classic symptoms of cholinergic toxicity (e.g., miosis, bradycardia, and diaphoresis), which makes this an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Isopropyl alcohol ingestion can cause altered mental status and elevated osmolar gap, which are seen in this patient. However, it would not explain the elevated anion gap or oxalate crystals in the urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin toxicity can cause altered mental status, vomiting, tachypnea, and an anion gap, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, this condition would not explain the urine oxalate crystals.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute encephalopathy, signs of tetany (muscle spasms), and hyperventilation. His laboratory studies are notable for an elevated anion gap AG = 137 - (99 + 8) = 30 and an elevated osmolar gap. The presence of oxalate crystals in the urine indicates that he ingested a substance that is metabolized to oxalate.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his neighbor 2 hours after ingesting an unknown substance in a suicide attempt. He is confused and unable to provide further history. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. His skin is dry. Pupils are 12 mm and minimally reactive to light. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used for the rapid reversal of an opioid overdose. Although opioid overdose can also cause altered mental status, it also typically manifests with significantly reduced respiratory drive, bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, and miosis.

B) CORRECT:

Physostigmine is the first-line treatment for anticholinergic syndrome because it crosses the blood-brain barrier and rapidly enhances parasympathetic signaling. In addition to the classic findings seen in this patient, an overdose of anticholinergic drugs can also cause urinary retention, decreased bowel sounds, and erythematous skin (due to compensatory cutaneous vasodilation from hyperthermia). Use of physostigmine is usually only warranted in cases in which pure anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., overdose with atropine, benztropine) is suspected but can also be considered in patients with anticholinergic poisoning due to other agents (e.g., antihistamines) if they present with features of severe central anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., delirium). Physostigmine should be avoided in patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose (TCA overdose) because of the risk of cardiac arrest. Ingestion of TCAs is unlikely in this patient as EKG findings are normal. Physostigmine should be administered carefully and patients should be monitored for cholinergic toxicity.

Key learning point: Physostigmine is the antidote for severe anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by delirium, mydriasis, dry skin, hyperthermia, and tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is used for the treatment of acetaminophen overdose to restore depleted hepatic glutathione, which is needed for the conjugation and excretion of the toxic acetaminophen metabolites. These patients typically present nonspecifically with nausea and vomiting before eventually progressing to liver failure (if not treated), in contrast to the acute, severe reaction seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used in the treatment of beta blocker overdose, as it activates adenylate cyclase during depolarization, raising intracellular cAMP levels and improving cardiac contractility. Overdose with these drugs typically manifests with pronounced bradycardia, cardiogenic shock, altered mental status, wheezing (due to bronchoconstriction), and hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil may be indicated for severe cases of benzodiazepine overdose, which could explain this patient's signs of central nervous system depression, such as decreased respiratory rate and altered mental status. However, benzodiazepine toxicity typically also causes hyporeflexia and does not cause hypertension, elevated temperature, dry skin, or mydriasis.
questions.hint: The symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome can be remembered as: "Blind as a bat (mydriasis), mad as a hatter (delirium), red as a beet (flushing), hot as a hare (hyperthermia), dry as a bone (decreased secretions and dry skin), the bowel and bladder lose their tone (urinary retention and paralytic ileus), and the heart runs alone (tachycardia).”

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of abdominal pain that started one hour ago after drinking from a bottle of toilet cleaner. The mother reports that he vomited once on the way to the hospital and his vomit was nonbloody. The patient has pain with swallowing. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Examination shows heavy salivation. Oral examination shows mild oral erythema in the area of the epiglottis, but no burns. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. The patient is intubated and oxygenation and intravenous fluid resuscitation are begun. All contaminated clothes are removed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute treatment of caustic ingestion includes airway management, supplemental oxygen, fluid resuscitation, and decontamination (e.g., removal of contaminated clothes). Upper endoscopy within 12–24 hours should be performed in symptomatic patients to assess the severity of esophageal injury and guide further therapy, such as the need for surgery. Endoscopy is contraindicated in cases of airway compromise (e.g., burns in the area of the epiglottis) and overt esophageal perforation seen on initial radiography imaging (e.g., x-ray or CT scan). If the airway is compromised, intubation needs to be performed first (as was done in this patient). In overt perforation, immediate surgery is required.

Long-term sequelae of caustic ingestion include esophageal strictures and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

B) INCORRECT:

A tube that is passed blindly through the esophagus into the stomach can damage the already-injured esophageal lining. Furthermore, gastric lavage can induce vomiting or push some of the stomach contents back into the esophagus. In both cases, the esophagus would again be exposed to the caustic agent, potentially causing further damage. Therefore, gastric lavage is contraindicated for the treatment of caustic ingestion.

C) INCORRECT:

Dilution should not be attempted as it increases the risk of vomiting. Vomiting would reintroduce the ingested caustic agent to the esophagus and cause damage to the already injured esophageal mucosa. Neutralizing the caustic agent with the application of acid is also absolutely contraindicated as this can lead to chemical reactions that would further damage the esophagus.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium upper gastrointestinal series is not part of the initial management of caustic ingestion. If there is a perforation, barium would leak into the mediastinum and potentially cause mediastinitis. If perforation is suspected, a water-soluble contrast agent should be used instead. Barium swallow may be useful for evaluating strictures or stenoses 2–3 weeks after the ingestion.

E) INCORRECT:

Inducing vomiting is contraindicated. The ingested caustic agent could cause further damage if it is regurgitated through the already damaged esophagus.
questions.hint: This patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, odynophagia, and heavy salivation that began shortly after ingestion of toilet cleaner, which often contains caustic substances.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department 30 minutes after accidentally ingesting a liquid drain cleaner containing a strong alkali. She complains of severe oropharyngeal pain, cough, and minimal drooling. She denies other ingestions and has not vomited. She reports persistent throat pain despite sipping small amounts of water (see report).
Imaging: No evidence of perforation
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Chemical neutralization with a weak acid solution
Endoscopic evaluation to assess esophageal injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neutralizing a strong alkali with a weak acid is hazardous due to the exothermic reaction, which can worsen tissue damage. Alkali ingestion causes liquefactive necrosis, and introducing an acid can lead to further burns. Current guidelines advise against chemical neutralization due to unpredictable reactions.

B) CORRECT:

Alkali ingestion causes liquefactive necrosis, leading to deep tissue injury that may not be evident on initial imaging. In stable patients, endoscopic evaluation within 12 to 24 hours post-ingestion is crucial to assess mucosal damage in the oropharynx, esophagus, and stomach. This evaluation uses standardized grading systems, such as the Zargar classification, to guide management by identifying injuries ranging from superficial edema to deep ulcerations. Recognizing injury severity through endoscopy is vital for predicting complications like strictures or perforation, informing further interventions and long-term management.

Key learning point: In cases of caustic ingestion, inducing emesis, dilution, or gastric lavage are contraindicated due to the risk of further injury; close observation and supportive care are the appropriate management steps.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in caustic ingestions due to the risk of mechanical trauma and perforation. Alkali ingestion causes liquefactive necrosis, making tissues vulnerable. Lavage can exacerbate damage by re-exposing mucosa to caustic material, increasing the risk of further injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Inducing emesis in caustic ingestions, such as with strong alkalis, can worsen injury by re-exposing tissues to the corrosive agent. Vomiting risks further esophageal and oropharyngeal damage and potential aspiration, contradicting management protocols that prioritize airway protection and careful evaluation.

questions.text:
Two days after being admitted to hospital, a 74-year-old man develops confusion and headache. He has also been vomiting for the past hour. His temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 98/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. He is lethargic and oriented only to person. Examination reveals flushed skin. Fundoscopic examination shows bright red retinal veins. Serum studies are as follows:


Sodium (Na), blood
138 mmol/L (136–146)


Potassium (K), blood
3.5 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Chloride (Cl), blood
100 mmol/L (98–107)


Bicarbonate (HCO3), blood
17 mmol/L (21–32)


Creatinine, blood
106 μmol/L (49–93)


Urea, blood
6.8 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Lactate, blood

8.0 mmol/L (0.5–2.5)


Glucose, fasting, blood
4.2 mmol/L (4.0–6.0)


Arterial blood gas pH

7.13 (7.38–7.46)


Which one of the following conditions was most likely being treated, resulting in this patient's current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxicity with benztropine, an anticholinergic agent used in the treatment of acute dystonia and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms, can manifest with tachycardia, flushing, and confusion. However, this patient lacks other typical features of anticholinergic toxicity, such as mydriasis. Additionally, his bright red retinal veins and high anion gap metabolic acidosis are not consistent with anticholinergic toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder can be treated with a variety of medications e.g., selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), or tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs). TCA overdose can manifest with confusion, tachycardia, flushing, and metabolic acidosis. However, this patient lacks other typical features of TCA overdose such as sedation, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Serotonin syndrome can manifest with confusion, tachycardia, and metabolic acidosis, but also usually causes neuromuscular excitability (e.g., tremor, hyperreflexia), hyperthermia, and diaphoresis. This patient's bright red retinal veins on fundoscopic examination are not typical for either syndrome and are suggestive of a different etiology.

C) CORRECT:

This patient most likely had a hypertensive crisis treated with intravenous sodium nitroprusside. Sodium nitroprusside contains cyanide groups and patients who receive prolonged or high-dose infusions or have kidney disease are at especially high risk of developing cyanide toxicity. Cyanide inhibits the electron transport chain and thereby disables aerobic metabolism, resulting in a switch to anaerobic metabolism that leads to elevated lactate levels and anion gap metabolic acidosis. Treatment of cyanide toxicity consists of 100% oxygen therapy and an antidote for cyanide poisoning (e.g., hydroxocobalamin).

The flushed skin and bright red retinal veins seen in patients with cyanide toxicity are a result of impaired oxygen utilization and increased venous oxygen saturation.

Key learning point: Sodium nitroprusside used for hypertensive crisis can cause cyanide toxicity, leading to lactic acidosis, confusion, flushed skin, and bright red venous blood due to impaired cellular oxygen utilization.

D) INCORRECT:

A variety of medications can be used in the treatment of refractory atrial fibrillation (e.g., digoxin, beta blockers, calcium channel blockers). Digoxin toxicity may manifest with headache, confusion, nausea, and vomiting. Beta blocker and calcium channel blocker toxicity can cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, flushed skin and bright red retinal veins are not common adverse effects of any of these medications. Additionally, this patient lacks other typical clinical features of cardiovascular drug poisoning (e.g., hypotension, bradycardia).

E) INCORRECT:

Type 2 diabetes mellitus is caused by peripheral insulin resistance and can be treated with a variety of different medications (e.g., insulin, sulfonylureas, metformin). A common side effect of most of these medications is hypoglycemia, which can manifest with confusion, nausea, and vomiting. In addition, metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis. However, none of these medications would explain the facial flushing and bright red retinal veins seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's confusion, headache, flushed skin, bright red retinal veins, high anion gap metabolic acidosis (AG = 138 - (100 + 17) = 21), and elevated lactate levels should raise concern for cyanide poisoning.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old girl in the emergency department. Her father reports that she began drooling and developed abdominal pain immediately after drinking from a bottle of drain cleaner 30 minutes ago. She had one episode of nonbloody vomiting on the way to the hospital and has pain with swallowing. She appears uncomfortable. Oral examination reveals mild erythema of the epiglottis and heavy salivation. Which one of the following long-term complications is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mallory-Weiss tears are traumatic mucosal and submucosal esophageal tears at the gastroesophageal junction. These tears usually manifest with hematemesis, and they are typically the result of severe, repeated retching and/or vomiting. In most affected individuals, Mallory-Weiss tears heal spontaneously. Conditions that predispose individuals to Mallory-Weiss tears include alcohol use disorder, bulimia nervosa, and gastroesophageal reflux disease, but not caustic agent injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cavity cancer is associated with long-term oral tobacco use, smoking, or alcohol consumption as well as poor oral hygiene and/or human papillomavirus (e.g., HPV 16, 18, 31, and 33) infection. Caustic agent injury is associated with an increased risk of esophageal cancer rather than oral cavity cancer.

C) CORRECT:

The most common long-term complication of caustic liquid ingestion is the development of esophageal strictures. Most strictures develop approximately 2 months after the initial injury. In patients with esophageal caustic injury, esophageal dysmotility (due to strictures and neuromuscular damage) can lead to severe dysphagia. Other long-term complications of caustic liquid ingestion include gastric outlet obstruction and esophageal cancer.

Acute complications of caustic liquid ingestion are esophageal ulcers and esophageal perforation, which can result in mediastinitis or peritonitis.

Key learning point: Esophageal stricture formation is the most common long-term complication following caustic ingestion due to scarring and fibrosis during the healing process.

D) INCORRECT:

Barrett esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux. Chronic gastroesophageal reflux may occur secondary to caustic-agent injury but Barrett esophagus is not a common complication.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue that protrude into the esophagus and can cause symptoms such as dysphagia, odynophagia, and food impaction. Esophageal webs can be seen in patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome, but they are not caused by ingesting caustic agents.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, odynophagia, and heavy salivation) began shortly after the ingestion of drain cleaner, which often contains caustic agents.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 47-year-old man who was brought to the emergency department 1 hour after being found collapsed on his front porch in a pool of vomitus by his neighbor. He is oriented only to self. His pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination reveals muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Laboratory studies show the following:


Sodium (Na), blood
137 mmol/L (136–146)


Chloride (Cl), blood
99 mmol/L (98–107)


Bicarbonate (HCO3), blood
8 mmol/L (21–32)


Serum osmolar gap
Elevated


Urinalysis
Oxalate crystals


Which one of the following substances is most likely responsible for this toxicity?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parathion is an organophosphate that can cause cholinergic toxicity. Although this patient's altered mental status and vomiting may also be seen in organophosphate poisoning, oxalate crystals would not be seen. Additionally, he lacks the other classic symptoms of cholinergic toxicity (e.g., miosis, bradycardia, and diaphoresis), which makes this an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Ethylene glycol is enzymatically oxidized by alcohol dehydrogenase, then aldehyde dehydrogenase, to form oxalate, glyoxylate, and glycolate. These metabolites collect in the renal system and are detectable in the urine as oxalate crystals, which can cause flank pain, hematuria, oliguria, and acute kidney injury. Hypocalcemia, the cause of this patient's tetany, is a result of calcium being consumed by oxalate to form calcium oxalate. Other signs of ethylene glycol poisoning include altered mental status and tachypnea (due to respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis). Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning consists of fomepizole to competitively inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase, as ethylene glycol itself is not nearly as toxic as its metabolites.

Key learning point: Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by high anion gap metabolic acidosis, elevated osmolar gap, and oxalate crystals in urine due to its metabolism to glycolate and oxalate.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin toxicity can cause altered mental status, vomiting, tachypnea, and an anion gap, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, this condition would not explain the urine oxalate crystals.

D) INCORRECT:

Isopropyl alcohol ingestion can cause altered mental status and elevated osmolar gap, which are seen in this patient. However, it would not explain the elevated anion gap or oxalate crystals in the urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Methanol is an alcohol that is metabolized to formate, a toxic substance that can cause end-organ damage. Although methanol poisoning would explain many of this man's symptoms (anion gap, altered mental status, elevated serum osmolar gap), the key distinguishing feature in this patient is the formation of urine oxalate crystals, which is not seen with methanol toxicity.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute encephalopathy, signs of tetany (muscle spasms), and hyperventilation. His laboratory studies are notable for an elevated anion gap AG = 137 - (99 + 8) = 30 and an elevated osmolar gap. The presence of oxalate crystals in the urine indicates that he ingested a substance that is metabolized to oxalate.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy brought to the emergency department by his mother because of abdominal pain that began one hour ago after he drank from a bottle of toilet cleaner. His mother reports that he vomited once on the way to the hospital; the vomit was nonbloody. He has pain with swallowing. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. On examination, he has heavy salivation. Oral examination reveals mild erythema in the area of the epiglottis, but no burns. A chest x-ray is normal. The patient is intubated, and oxygenation and intravenous fluid resuscitation are started. All contaminated clothes are removed. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilution should not be attempted as it increases the risk of vomiting. Vomiting would reintroduce the ingested caustic agent to the esophagus and cause damage to the already injured esophageal mucosa. Neutralizing the caustic agent with the application of acid is also absolutely contraindicated as this can lead to chemical reactions that would further damage the esophagus.

B) CORRECT:

Acute treatment of caustic ingestion includes airway management, supplemental oxygen, fluid resuscitation, and decontamination (e.g., removal of contaminated clothes). Upper endoscopy within 12–24 hours should be performed in symptomatic patients to assess the severity of esophageal injury and guide further therapy, such as the need for surgery. Endoscopy is contraindicated in cases of airway compromise (e.g., burns in the area of the epiglottis) and overt esophageal perforation seen on initial radiography imaging (e.g., x-ray or CT scan). If the airway is compromised, intubation needs to be performed first (as was done in this patient). In overt perforation, immediate surgery is required.

Long-term sequelae of caustic ingestion include esophageal strictures and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

Key learning point: After caustic ingestion, upper endoscopy within 12–24 hours is indicated to assess esophageal injury unless there is evidence of perforation or unprotected airway.

C) INCORRECT:

A tube that is passed blindly through the esophagus into the stomach can damage the already-injured esophageal lining. Furthermore, gastric lavage can induce vomiting or push some of the stomach contents back into the esophagus. In both cases, the esophagus would again be exposed to the caustic agent, potentially causing further damage. Therefore, gastric lavage is contraindicated for the treatment of caustic ingestion.

D) INCORRECT:

Inducing vomiting is contraindicated. The ingested caustic agent could cause further damage if it is regurgitated through the already damaged esophagus.

E) INCORRECT:

A barium upper gastrointestinal series is not part of the initial management of caustic ingestion. If there is a perforation, barium would leak into the mediastinum and potentially cause mediastinitis. If perforation is suspected, a water-soluble contrast agent should be used instead. Barium swallow may be useful for evaluating strictures or stenoses 2–3 weeks after the ingestion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, odynophagia, and heavy salivation that began shortly after ingestion of toilet cleaner, which often contains caustic substances.

questions.text: You are seeing a 56-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his neighbor 2 hours after ingesting an unknown substance in a suicide attempt. He is confused and unable to provide further history. His temperature is 39.1°C, pulse is 124/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. His skin is dry. Pupils are 12 mm and minimally reactive to light. An ECG is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is used for the treatment of acetaminophen overdose to restore depleted hepatic glutathione, which is needed for the conjugation and excretion of the toxic acetaminophen metabolites. These patients typically present nonspecifically with nausea and vomiting before eventually progressing to liver failure (if not treated), in contrast to the acute, severe reaction seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil may be indicated for severe cases of benzodiazepine overdose, which could explain this patient's signs of central nervous system depression, such as decreased respiratory rate and altered mental status. However, benzodiazepine toxicity typically also causes hyporeflexia and does not cause hypertension, elevated temperature, dry skin, or mydriasis.

C) CORRECT:

Physostigmine is the first-line treatment for anticholinergic syndrome because it crosses the blood-brain barrier and rapidly enhances parasympathetic signaling. In addition to the classic findings seen in this patient, an overdose of anticholinergic drugs can also cause urinary retention, decreased bowel sounds, and erythematous skin (due to compensatory cutaneous vasodilation from hyperthermia). Use of physostigmine is usually only warranted in cases in which pure anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., overdose with atropine, benztropine) is suspected but can also be considered in patients with anticholinergic poisoning due to other agents (e.g., antihistamines) if they present with features of severe central anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., delirium). Physostigmine should be avoided in patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose (TCA overdose) because of the risk of cardiac arrest. Ingestion of TCAs is unlikely in this patient as EKG findings are normal. Physostigmine should be administered carefully and patients should be monitored for cholinergic toxicity.

Key learning point: Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for severe anticholinergic toxicity because it reversibly inhibits acetylcholinesterase and crosses the blood-brain barrier to restore cholinergic function.

D) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used for the rapid reversal of an opioid overdose. Although opioid overdose can also cause altered mental status, it also typically manifests with significantly reduced respiratory drive, bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, and miosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used in the treatment of beta blocker overdose, as it activates adenylate cyclase during depolarization, raising intracellular cAMP levels and improving cardiac contractility. Overdose with these drugs typically manifests with pronounced bradycardia, cardiogenic shock, altered mental status, wheezing (due to bronchoconstriction), and hypotension.
questions.hint: The symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome can be remembered as: "Blind as a bat (mydriasis), mad as a hatter (delirium), red as a beet (flushing), hot as a hare (hyperthermia), dry as a bone (decreased secretions and dry skin), the bowel and bladder lose their tone (urinary retention and paralytic ileus), and the heart runs alone (tachycardia).”

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by family members after being found appearing confused and drowsy. The patient has a history of chronic pain and depression. Vital signs are BP, 110/68; P, 58; R, 10; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F); oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. Physical examination shows 2-mm pupils that are sluggishly reactive to light and decreased bowel sounds. The patient responds only to verbal stimuli. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While arterial blood gas analysis may provide useful information, this patient requires immediate therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Psychiatric consultation for risk assessment is appropriate later in the clinical course, but the acute toxicological emergency must be addressed first.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine toxicology screening may be helpful for confirming the diagnosis but does not change immediate management.

D) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is used for gastrointestinal decontamination in recent ingestions but is not the best immediate next step for this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic opioid toxidrome characterized by miosis, respiratory depression, altered mental status, decreased bowel sounds, and bradycardia. Naloxone administration is the most appropriate next step to reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression and altered mental status.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents 45 minutes after ingesting drain cleaner containing potassium hydroxide during a suicide attempt. He reports severe throat pain and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination shows oral mucosal ulceration, drooling, and mild stridor. He is anxious but alert, with stable vital signs. The patient can speak in full sentences, but his voice is hoarse. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Nasogastric tube placement for gastric lavage
CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy is indicated within 12–24 hours to assess mucosal injury, but immediate airway management takes priority when stridor is present. Early endoscopy should be delayed until the airway is secured.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has signs of airway compromise. Caustic ingestion can cause rapidly progressive airway edema, and early intubation is essential when signs of airway compromise are present.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube placement is contraindicated in caustic ingestion, as it can cause further tissue damage and perforation.

D) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is appropriate to evaluate for perforation, but securing the airway takes immediate priority when stridor is present. Imaging can be obtained after airway management.

E) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is not effective in caustic ingestion, as it does not bind caustic agents and increases risk of gastrointestinal perforation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old maintenance worker presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after accidentally splashing industrial drain cleaner containing hydrochloric acid into his mouth while working on a clogged sink. He reports severe oral burning pain, difficulty swallowing, and worsening epigastric pain. Physical examination shows oral mucosal ulcerations with white plaques, oropharyngeal edema, and epigastric tenderness. His voice is hoarse. Vital signs are T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); P, 98; BP, 135/85; R, 20; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Give oral milk to neutralize remaining acid
Obtain CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast
Perform immediate endoscopy to assess mucosal damage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neutralization with any substance, including milk, is contraindicated in caustic ingestion as neutralization can worsen tissue damage through heat generation from the neutralization reaction and may induce vomiting.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are not indicated in caustic ingestion unless there is evidence of infection or perforation. The immediate priority is assessing for structural complications.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast is indicated to assess for esophageal or gastric perforation, which are life-threatening complications of caustic ingestion. A hoarse voice and progressive symptoms suggest significant mucosal injury, necessitating evaluation for perforation before endoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy should be performed within 12–24 hours but is not the next step in management. CT imaging should be obtained first to rule out perforation, as endoscopy can worsen existing perforations and is contraindicated if perforation is present.

E) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are not routinely recommended in acute caustic ingestion management. The priority is assessing for complications such as perforation rather than acid suppression therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 3 hours after accidentally ingesting approximately 15 mL of drain cleaner containing sodium hydroxide while cleaning her kitchen sink. She reports severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and retrosternal chest pain. Physical examination shows oral mucosal erythema and mild pharyngeal edema. Vital signs are normal with no signs of respiratory distress. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Schedule barium swallow study to evaluate esophageal injury
Obtain CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast
Administer diluted milk to neutralize the alkali
Perform immediate laryngoscopy to assess airway

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While endoscopy within 12–24 hours is essential for evaluating caustic ingestion, another management step should be performed first.

B) INCORRECT:

Barium swallow study is not recommended for immediate evaluation of caustic ingestion because of the risk of mediastinitis or peritonitis in patients with esophageal perforation; additionally, oral contrast can interfere with subsequent endoscopic evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast is the initial imaging study of choice to evaluate for signs of perforation, peritonitis, or mediastinitis that would require urgent surgical intervention. CT chest and abdomen must precede endoscopy to ensure patient safety and guide management decisions.

D) INCORRECT:

Neutralization attempts with milk or other substances are contraindicated in caustic ingestion because they can cause heat production, vomiting, or further tissue damage. The alkali has already caused tissue injury within minutes of ingestion.

E) INCORRECT:

Immediate laryngoscopy is not indicated in this stable patient without signs of airway compromise or respiratory distress. The patient's normal vital signs and lack of respiratory symptoms do not warrant emergency airway assessment.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with chronic kidney disease is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious in his apartment following a kitchen fire. He was intubated in the field for altered mental status. Vital signs are BP, 70/40; P, 130; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). Laboratory results show pH 7.20, HCO3- 10 mEq/L, anion gap 20 mEq/L, and lactate 12 mmol/L. Carboxyhemoglobin level is 15%. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hyperbaric oxygen may be considered for severe carbon monoxide poisoning, the combination of fire exposure, severe lactic acidosis, and altered mental status suggests concurrent cyanide poisoning requiring immediate antidotal therapy rather than hyperbaric treatment alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Methylene blue treats methemoglobinemia by reducing methemoglobin back to hemoglobin. Methylene blue does not address the inhibition of cytochrome complex IV caused by cyanide and would not improve this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Sodium nitrite is a second-line cyanide antidote that induces methemoglobinemia. In patients with concurrent carbon monoxide poisoning, creating methemoglobin can worsen tissue hypoxia and should be avoided when hydroxocobalamin is available.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Hydroxocobalamin is the first-line antidote for suspected cyanide poisoning. Fire exposure with altered mental status, hemodynamic instability, and severe lactic acidosis > 8 mmol/L suggests cyanide poisoning requiring immediate empiric antidotal therapy regardless of carboxyhemoglobin levels.

E) INCORRECT:

While the patient has chronic kidney disease, continuous renal replacement therapy does not address the cellular toxicity from cyanide poisoning. This patient's severe lactic acidosis is due to blocked oxidative phosphorylation, not renal dysfunction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought in by her family 36 hours after a suicide attempt in which she ingested a large quantity of rodenticide that contained brodifacoum. She reports abdominal pain and bloody urine. Vital signs are BP, 110/75; P, 95. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and diffuse mild abdominal tenderness without guarding. INR is 4.2, hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL, and platelet count is 280,000/μL. Poison control states the ingestion is likely to be toxic. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Administer oral vitamin K and monitor INR
Transfuse packed red blood cells and repeat hemoglobin in 6 hours
Administer fresh frozen plasma and admit for observation
Initiate IV vitamin K and prothrombin complex concentrate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral vitamin K takes 24–48 hours to affect INR and is too slow for managing active hemorrhage from superwarfarin poisoning.

B) INCORRECT:

While hematuria warrants investigation under normal circumstances, this patient's bleeding is clearly related to anticoagulant toxicity based on the recent brodifacoum ingestion and elevated INR. The underlying coagulopathy must be addressed before urologic evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood transfusion may be necessary for severe anemia but does not address the underlying coagulopathy causing continued bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Fresh frozen plasma can provide temporary coagulation factors but should be combined with IV vitamin K for optimal management. Fresh frozen plasma alone does not address the underlying mechanism of superwarfarin toxicity.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has active hemorrhage from superwarfarin poisoning. Management of active bleeding requires IV vitamin K plus 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate for immediate coagulation factor replacement and rapid reversal of anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after ingesting drain cleaner. The child has oral erythema, tongue swelling, and drooling. After successful intubation for airway protection, vital signs are normal. The child now appears comfortable on mechanical ventilation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform immediate endoscopy to assess injury extent
Administer activated charcoal via nasogastric tube
Obtain CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast
Obtain barium swallow study to evaluate for perforation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate endoscopy is not recommended. Endoscopy should be arranged within 12–24 hours of ingestion; performing endoscopy too early may not accurately assess the full extent of injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is ineffective in caustic ingestions and may obscure endoscopic visualization. Gastrointestinal decontamination should be avoided in caustic exposures.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not indicated in caustic ingestion management. Treatment focuses on assessing for complications, supportive care, and specialist consultation for definitive management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- After airway stabilization in caustic ingestion, CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast is indicated to assess for esophageal perforation, gastric perforation, and mediastinitis. This imaging helps determine the need for urgent surgery and guides further management decisions.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral contrast imaging such as barium swallow is not recommended in caustic ingestion because it may worsen injury and does not provide adequate assessment for perforation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old maintenance worker is brought to the emergency department after cleaning machinery in a poorly ventilated area using an industrial degreaser. Coworkers found him confused and complaining of burning skin. He has visible erythema on his exposed arms and neck, mild tachypnea, and a chemical odor on his clothing. Vital signs are BP, 145/85; P, 105; R, 20; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Administer supplemental oxygen and obtain arterial blood gas
Remove clothing and irrigate affected skin with copious amounts of water
Contact poison control center for specific antidote recommendations
Obtain chest radiograph to assess for pulmonary edema
Establish intravenous access and administer crystalloid fluids

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supplemental oxygen and arterial blood gas analysis address respiratory concerns, but they are not the most appropriate initial step in management for this patient's chemical exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Body surface decontamination is the immediate priority following chemical exposure. This involves removing all contaminated clothing and irrigating affected areas with large volumes of water for 10–15 minutes to halt ongoing absorption and protect health care providers from secondary exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

Poison control consultation is valuable for ongoing management and specific antidote guidance, but it is not the most appropriate initial step in management for this patient's chemical exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

While chest imaging may be indicated to evaluate for chemical pneumonitis, it is not the most appropriate initial step in management for this patient's chemical exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous access is important for ongoing care, but it is not the most appropriate initial step in management for this patient's chemical exposure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with chest pain, odynophagia, and nausea that began 3 hours ago. He reports accidentally drinking from an unmarked container while cleaning his garage. Physical examination reveals oral erythema and mild abdominal tenderness. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate diagnostic evaluation to assess for complications?

choices.text: CT chest and abdomen without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs do not adequately visualize mucosal injury, perforation, or mediastinitis that can occur with caustic ingestion.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral contrast imaging such as barium swallow is not recommended for evaluating caustic injuries due to the risk of complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy should be performed within 12–24 hours but is not appropriate as an urgent diagnostic procedure. Initial imaging evaluation should be completed first to assess for perforation and other complications.

D) INCORRECT:

CT without contrast does not provide adequate assessment of tissue perfusion and injury. IV contrast is essential to evaluate for perforation, identify areas of tissue damage, and assess for complications such as mediastinitis that require urgent surgical intervention.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast is the appropriate study to evaluate for indications requiring urgent surgery, including esophageal perforation, gastric perforation, and mediastinitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department 8 hours after consuming wild mushrooms foraged from a local forest. The patient reports severe abdominal pain, profuse watery diarrhea, and vomiting that began 6 hours ago. Vital signs are notable for mild tachycardia and hypotension consistent with dehydration. The patient appears unwell but is alert and oriented without neurological deficits. Initial laboratory studies show normal liver function tests and coagulation studies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with Amanita phalloides poisoning. The onset of gastrointestinal symptoms 6–8 hours after ingestion, absence of neurological symptoms, and normal initial liver function tests are characteristic of the early phase of hepatotoxic mushroom poisoning. Silibinin is the first-line antidote for A. phalloides poisoning and should be administered as soon as possible in consultation with poison control, even before liver dysfunction develops.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines are used to treat agitation in Amanita muscaria poisoning, which causes mixed excitatory and inhibitory neuropsychiatric effects. This patient has no neurological symptoms, and the isolated gastrointestinal presentation suggests hepatotoxic rather than neurotoxic mushroom poisoning.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylene blue treats methemoglobinemia, which can occur with Gyromitra poisoning. However, this patient lacks the neurological symptoms typical of Gyromitra poisoning; their symptoms are consistent with the classic gastrointestinal phase of hepatotoxic mushroom poisoning instead.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine is the antidote for Gyromitra poisoning, which manifests with seizures due to inhibition of pyridoxal phosphate synthesis. This patient lacks neurological symptoms, and the timing of gastrointestinal symptoms is more consistent with A. phalloides than Gyromitra poisoning.

E) INCORRECT:

Atropine is used to treat cholinergic crisis. This patient's presentation is more consistent with a different type of poisoning.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after ingesting unknown berries while hiking. She is disoriented, has visual hallucinations, and reports feeling hot. Vital signs are BP, 118/76; P, 142; R, 20; T, 40.1°C (104.2°F). Physical examination shows flushed skin with decreased sweating, mydriasis, dry mucous membranes, and a distended bladder. Bowel sounds are absent. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia without QRS or QTc prolongation. What is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used for opioid overdose and does not reverse anticholinergic toxidrome. This patient's clinical presentation is inconsistent with opioid toxicity.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with anticholinergic toxidrome from belladonna poisoning. Initial management focuses on supportive care, including active cooling for hyperthermia.

C) INCORRECT:

Whole bowel irrigation is not a standard treatment for anticholinergic toxidrome and does not address the immediate need for supportive care and temperature control.

D) INCORRECT:

Atropine worsens anticholinergic toxidrome, as it is a competitive muscarinic receptor inhibitor.

E) INCORRECT:

A comprehensive toxicology screen does not change immediate management and delays necessary supportive care for this patient with clear anticholinergic toxidrome.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after ingesting an unknown quantity of a multi-component bathroom cleaner containing sodium hydroxide, quaternary ammonium compounds, and surfactants. The child is alert with mild oral erythema and refuses to swallow. Vital signs are normal. The parents report that the child was found with the open container, but they are unsure how much was consumed. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: CT chest and abdomen with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Multi-component cleaning products contain substances of varying toxicity that require specialist evaluation. Poison control consultation provides immediate 24/7 support to determine the specific toxicity risk of complex household products and guide management priorities.

B) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors have no established role in caustic ingestion management and do not address the immediate need for toxicity assessment of the multi-component product.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastroenterology consultation may be appropriate after initial risk assessment, but another management step is the immediate priority to determine the extent of toxicity and guide specialist referral timing.

D) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is indicated for signs of perforation or significant injury, but the patient's current presentation requires initial risk stratification to determine the appropriate next steps.

E) INCORRECT:

While endoscopy within 12–24 hours may be indicated for caustic ingestions, another step is indicated before proceeding with invasive procedures.

questions.text: A 35-year-old hiker presents 18 hours after consuming foraged mushrooms with nausea and profuse diarrhea that began 8 hours post-ingestion. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination reveals mild dehydration. Laboratory studies show normal hepatic function and creatinine. The patient reports feeling somewhat better over the past few hours. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate, as this patient's presentation suggests the latent phase of Amanita phalloides poisoning. Individuals may experience transient improvement in the latent phase, which follows the initial gastrointestinal phase. The potentially fatal hepatorenal phase begins 2–6 days after ingestion.

B) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is not effective 18 hours after ingestion, as gastrointestinal decontamination is only useful in the immediate post-ingestion period.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose IV penicillin G is the second-line antidote for Amanita phalloides poisoning. Another treatment is first-line.

D) INCORRECT:

IV pyridoxine is the specific antidote for poisoning with Gyromitra mushrooms (false morels), not for Amanita phalloides.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – IV silibinin is the first-line antidote for suspected Amanita phalloides poisoning and should be administered as soon as possible, even during the latent phase, when patients may feel better.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suspected suicide attempt involving the ingestion of an unknown liquid drain cleaner. He is agitated, drooling, and complains of severe retrosternal pain and odynophagia. His pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination reveals erythematous mucosa with ulcerations on the posterior pharynx and a hoarse voice. The abdomen is tender in the epigastrium. A chest radiograph is unremarkable for acute abnormalities. After initial stabilization, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Nasogastric tube placement for gastric lavage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placing a nasogastric tube is absolutely contraindicated following caustic ingestion. The damaged esophageal tissue is extremely friable, and blind passage of a tube carries a very high risk of iatrogenic perforation. Furthermore, gastric lavage or the administration of neutralizing agents is not recommended, as it can induce vomiting, causing re-exposure of the esophagus to the caustic agent.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for caustic ingestion. The most critical step after initial resuscitation is to determine the extent and severity of the injury to the upper gastrointestinal tract. Flexible esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the gold standard diagnostic procedure for this purpose. It allows for direct visualization of the oropharynx, esophagus, stomach, and duodenum to evaluate the extent of damage. EGD should be performed within 12 to 24 hours of ingestion, as performing it later increases the risk of iatrogenic perforation when tissues become more friable.

C) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow is useful for evaluating chronic complications of caustic ingestion, such as esophageal strictures. However, it is contraindicated in the acute setting because it provides poor visualization of mucosal detail, carries a high risk of aspiration, and can cause severe inflammatory mediastinitis if an esophageal perforation is present.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient requires admission and close observation, a diagnostic procedure is needed at this point to assess the extent of injury. The severity of oral burns and clinical symptoms correlates poorly with the degree of esophageal and gastric damage, so relying on observation alone is insufficient and can delay appropriate intervention.
questions.hint: After initial stabilization, the management of caustic ingestion depends on directly visualizing and grading the severity of the mucosal injury to the esophagus and stomach.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and headache for the past 6 hours. Three days ago, she was started on dapsone and rifampin for the treatment of tuberculoid leprosy. Her pulse is 115/min and respirations are 12/min. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips and nail beds. A venous blood sample appears chocolate-colored and does not change color when exposed to oxygen. Compared to a healthy child, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?



%O2 saturation
O2 partial pressure
O2 content
Hb concentration



A
Normal
normal
increased
increased


B
Normal
normal
decreased
decreased


C
Decreased
normal
decreased
normal


D
Decreased
decreased
decreased
normal


E
Decreased
normal
decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with polycythemia vera (PV), a condition characterized by an increase in erythrocyte count and thus hemoglobin (Hb) concentration. While this results in an increased arterial O2 content, O2 partial pressure and O2 saturation remain normal because these parameters mainly depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which is affected by increased Hb concentration. Classical manifestations of PV include facial flushing and pruritus, neither of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, respiratory depression, which is seen here, would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with anemia, which is characterized by low serum concentrations of hemoglobin (Hb) and, as a consequence, reduced arterial O2 content. O2 partial pressure and O2 saturation remain normal because these parameters mainly depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which is affected by low Hb concentration. Anemia can cause tachycardia, which is seen in this patient, but pallor rather than cyanosis would be expected. Moreover, chocolate-colored blood that does not change color when exposed to oxygen is not seen in anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Methemoglobinemia is caused by an abundance of methemoglobin, an altered form of hemoglobin in which ferrous iron (Fe2+) is oxidized to the ferric form (Fe3+). Since Fe3+ cannot bind oxygen, arterial O2 saturation and total O2 content decrease. This leads to functional anemia, despite normal hemoglobin concentrations. Patients with methemoglobinemia show clinical signs of cyanosis due to poor tissue oxygenation. O2 partial pressure (PaO2), which reflects the concentration of dissolved oxygen in plasma, is not affected. In patients prone to developing methemoglobinemia (e.g., patients with G6PD deficiency), oxidant drugs such as dapsone and topical anesthetic drugs should be avoided. Treatment consists of converting methemoglobin to hemoglobin by using reducing agents such as methylene blue and vitamin C.

Although prolonged or chronic methemoglobinemia may lead to erythrocytosis or polycythemia, this patient has only been taking her medication for three days.

See “Overview of factors that affect oxygenation” table.

D) INCORRECT:

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with hypoxemia (e.g., due to impaired gas exchange in the lungs). Impaired oxygenation of the blood decreases both the amount of oxygen dissolved in the plasma (↓ PaO2) and the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin (↓ SaO2). As a result, the total amount of oxygen transported by arterial blood (i.e., O2 content) will also be reduced. In states of hypoxemia, the hemoglobin concentration is initially unaffected, but may eventually increase due to stimulation of erythropoietin secretion. Hypoxemia can cause signs of cyanosis, which are seen here. However, unlike this patient's blood sample, deoxygenated blood changes color to bright red upon exposure to oxygen.

E) INCORRECT:

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with chronic carbon monoxide poisoning (e.g., from cigarette smoke). Since carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin (Hb) with much higher affinity than oxygen (producing carboxyhemoglobin), it cannot easily be displaced. This results in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which impairs oxygen delivery to the tissues. The amount of oxygen bound to Hb (SaO2) as well as the total arterial O2 content are reduced, while the amount of dissolved oxygen in the plasma (PaO2) remains unaffected. Elevated erythropoietin production secondary to chronic hypoxia induces an increase in Hb. Clinical findings of chronic carbon monoxide include dizziness and seizures, neither of which is seen here. Moreover, based on this patient's history, there is no reason to expect prolonged exposure to CO.
questions.hint: In a patient undergoing treatment with dapsone, tachycardia, respiratory depression, cyanosis, and chocolate-colored blood on venous sampling should raise suspicion for acute methemoglobinemia.
